citation.article-title: Tsukamurella gen. nov. harboring Corynebacterium paurometabolum and Rhodococcus aurantiacus.

p.s: Description of Tsukamurella gen. nov.
Tsukamurella (Tsuk.am.ur.el'la. M.L. dim. ending ella; M.L. fem. n. Tsukamurella, honoring Michio Tsukamura, a Japanese microbiologist)
Gram-positive, weakly acid-fast (some strains are strongly acid fast), non-sporeforming, rod-shaped cells.
Nonmotile.
Obligately aerobic.
Chemoorganotrophic.
Acid is produced from some sugars.
Catalase is produced.
Pyrazinamidase positive.
The diagnostic amino acid of peptidoglycan is meso-diaminopimelic acid (variation A1Î³; the glycan moiety of cell walls contains N-glycolyl residues.
The major cell wall sugars are arabinose and galactose.
Longchain mycolic acids are present (overall size, 62 to 78 carbon atoms) and contain one to six double bonds.
The fatty acid esters released on pyrolysis of mycolic acids have 20 to 22 carbon atoms.
The long-chain cellular fatty acids are predominantly of the straight-chain saturated, monounsaturated, and 10-methyl branched types.
The major polar lipids are diphosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylethanolamine, phosphatidylinositol, and mono- and diacylated phosphatidylinositol dimannosides.
Some strains produce glycolipids.
Menaquinones are the sole respiratory quinones, with MK-9 predominating.
The guanine-plus-cytosine content of the DNA is 67 to 68 mol%.
The type species of Tsukamurella is Tsukamurella paurometabolum.
